section.title: Investigating Trigonometric Identities
section.p: Suppose we were asked to solve the equation \sin\left(x\right)+\sin\left(-x\right)=0. We could accomplish this by using technology to graph and find the zeros of the function f\left(x\right)=\sin\left(x\right)+\sin\left(-x\right)=0. If we proceed with this approach, we will find that the graph of f\left(x\right)=\sin\left(x\right)+\sin\left(-x\right)=0 is identical to the graph of g\left(x\right)=0 over the entire domain of f. This implies that f\left(x\right)=0 for all x-values. Therefore, the equation \sin\left(x\right)+\sin\left(-x\right)=0 is true for all values of x. Recall that an equation that is true for all values of the variable is called an identity. The terms in the identity \sin\left(x\right)+\sin\left(-x\right)=0 can easily be rewritten to produce \sin\left(-x\right)=-\sin\left(x\right). This identity should be a familiar one. It is the algebraic statement that h\left(x\right)=\sin\left(x\right) is an odd function.
In this investigation you will use graphs, the unit circle, right triangles, and algebra to show that various equations are identities.

ol.li: Graph each function whose equation is given. Based on what you know about transformations and trigonometry, write a second equation whose graph would be identical to the one you have graphed. For example, if the given function were f\left(x\right)=\sin\left(-x\right)=0, then the equation g\left(x\right)=-\sin\left(x\right) produces an identical graph. Therefore, you know that \sin\left(x\right)=-\sin\left(x\right) is an identity. If you find several answers, record them all.

li.p: The coordinates of points labeled on the unit circle in Figure 5.1 suggest several identities. For example, point P has coordinates \left(a,b \right) and point Q has coordinates \left(b,a \right) because it is the mirror image of P over the line y=x.

Point P is the endpoint of an arc of length \theta that begins at \left(1,0 \right), and point Q is the endpoint of an arc of length \frac{\pi}{2}-\theta. The x-coordinate of P is the same as the y-coordinate of Q. This yields the identity \cos\left(\theta\right)=\sin\left(\frac{\pi}{2}-\theta \right).

Determine the coordinates of points R, S, T, U, V, and W in terms of a and b. Then write at least two other identities suggested by the coordinates you have labeled. Your identities should involve the sine, the cosine, or the tangent functions.

It is often possible to write new identities based on your existing knowledge of identities. Use algebra and known identities to establish each new identity.
